title: Default Bulk Ordering and Text Messaging to Enhance Outreach for Lipid Screening A Randomized Clinical Trial
abstract: IMPORTANCE A comprehensive lipid panel is recommended by guidelines to evaluate atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk, but uptake is low. OBJECTIVE To evaluate whether direct outreach including bulk orders with and without text messaging increases lipid screening rates. DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS Pragmatic randomized clinical trial conducted from June 6, 2023, to September 6, 2023, at 2 primary care practices at an academic health system among patients aged 20 to 75 years with at least 1 primary care visit in the past 3 years who were overdue for lipid screening. Data analysis was performed from September 2023 to May 2024. INTERVENTIONS Eligible patients were randomized in a 1:2:2 ratio to usual care (group 1), direct outreach and bulk orders (group 2), and bulk order outreach with additional text message reminders for scheduling assistance (group 3). In group 3, participants received an initial, follow-up, and reminder text message. Patients with electronic portal accounts were encouraged to schedule through them, while others received laboratory contact information. Any participant inquiries were answered either with automated responses for common questions or with study team support. MAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES Proportion of patients who completed a lipid panel within 3 months. RESULTS Among the 1000 participants, the median (IQR) age was 38 (28-55) years; 470 (47.0%) were female; and 22 (2.3%) were Asian, 38 (3.9%) were Black, 32 (3.2%) were Hispanic or Latino, and 862 (88.6%) were White (race and ethnicity were based on self-reported data). At 3 months, a lipid panel was completed by 12 of 202 patients (5.9%; 95% CI, 3.4% to 10.1%) receiving usual care (group 1) vs 62 of 394 patients (15.7%; 95% CI, 12.5% to 19.7%) receiving direct outreach and bulk order (group 2), a difference of 9.8 percentage points (95% CI, 4.6 to 15.0; P = .001). The panel was completed by 73 of 404 patients (18.1%; 95% CI, 14.6% to 22.1%) receiving outreach, bulk order, and text message reminders (group 3), for a difference of 2.4 percentage points (95% CI, -3.1 to 7.8; P = .43) vs outreach with bulk order alone (group 2). At 6 months, there were no significant differences in lipid screening between either group 1 vs group 2 or group 2 vs group 3. CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE Lipid screening among participants receiving bulk orders and outreach letters increased significantly compared with usual care at 3 months. However, there was no difference at 6 months. More than 80% of patients did not follow through with lipid screening despite the intervention, and there was no additional increase in lipid testing at 3 months among participants receiving bulk ordering and supplemental text messaging.

sections.text:
A therosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) remains a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Guidelines recommend routinely assessing traditional cardiovascular risk factors every 4 to 6 years for adults aged 20 to 39 years and both routinely assessing traditional cardiovascular risk factors and calculating the 10-year ASCVD risk for adults aged 40 to 75 years.  1 For many eligible patients, ASCVD risk cannot be calculated due to a missing comprehensive lipid panel measuring key components for ASCVD risk, such as total and high-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels. Monitoring of lipid profiles is essential in both primary and secondary prevention strategies. In many populations, a high proportion of patients may not have recent laboratory testing; a study by Gao et al  2  found that overall in the US, 27.5% of patients had not had a cholesterol screening within the last 5 years. To adhere to guidelines, the clinician has to recommend and order lipid screening, and the patient has to follow through and have laboratory samples drawn.

There are opportunities to overcome this challenge by leveraging insights from the field of behavioral science, as humans have systematic biases or heuristics that impede participation in health prevention activities.  [3] [4] 4] [5]  Behavioral economics use human psychology to develop nudges that change the choice architecture to lead people to make better decisions.  6 or example, shifting from an opt-in approach to opt-out default framing can nudge patients toward preventive screening while maintaining patient autonomy.  7, 8 With bulk ordering of lipid panels for overdue patients of a practice, lipid screening can be presented as the default choice, helping patients to overcome inertia from status quo bias. Including a signed laboratory order also reduces effort from both patients and clinicians. Patients may trust the recommendation of their primary care clinician to overcome hesitance due to the behavioral principle of social norms.  [9] [10] 0] [11]  Finally, including a time-limited component induces a deadline that can enhance moving from intention to action.  12 n addition, text message reminders have facilitated more efficient and equitable outreach by health systems, as most patients have and use a phone with texting capabilities.  13, 14 eriodic prompts and reminders can be an effective method to encourage and reinforce healthy behavior.  15, 16 Furthermore, offering information about the closest laboratory and available walk-in hours might facilitate screening by reducing logistical barriers.

In this randomized clinical trial, we evaluated the effectiveness of mailed outreach with bulk ordering and the integration of text messaging and scheduling support on completion of lipid screening among primary care patients.

sections.title: Study Design
sections.text:
Using a pragmatic format, this randomized, 3-arm parallelgroup trial evaluated usual care vs 2 modes of behaviorally informed outreach to determine whether the latter 2 modes increase uptake of lipid screening. Patients were randomized to the following study groups: usual care (no intervention; group 1), mailed outreach letter with a bulk signed laboratory slip (outreach + bulk order; group 2), or mailed outreach letter with a bulk signed laboratory slip with text messaging reminding patients to schedule an appointment and allowing them to ask questions or start a conversation for assistance (outreach + bulk order + text messaging; group 3).

The study was approved by the institutional review board at the University of Pennsylvania. A waiver of informed consent was obtained since the study was of minimal risk to patients, was embedded in clinical operations, and could not have been practicably carried out without the waiver. The protocol and statistical analysis plan are available in Supplement 1. This trial followed the Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials (CONSORT) reporting guidelines for randomized clinical trials. There were no major changes to the protocol before trial launch or after trial recruitment. Data analysis was performed from September 2023 to May 2024.

sections.title: Study Population
sections.text:
Patients were selected from 2 primary care practices that included a total of 14 clinicians from the University of Pennsylvania Health System in southeastern Pennsylvania. Using our electronic health record (EHR), we identified all patients aged 20 to 75 years who were overdue for a lipid panel according to Health Maintenance (patients who had no lipid panel in the past 5 years, or those with diabetes or an annual lipid check modifier without a lipid panel for >1 year). Eligible patients had a primary care physician (PCP) listed in 1 of the 2 primary care practices, had at least 1 visit in the past 3 years, and had health insurance. We excluded patients who did not have a cellular phone number listed in the EHR and patients who had a preferred laboratory outside the health system. We also excluded patients with medical conditions that could markedly diminish the potential benefits of lipid screening, such as those diagnosed with metastatic cancer or currently receiving hospice or palliative care.

Sociodemographic data were obtained from the EHR through automated data extraction. Race and ethnicity were based on self-reported data in the EHR and analyzed to understand differential response to interventions since there are known disparities in uptake. Race included Asian, Black, Hispanic, White, and other (American Indian or Alaska Native, Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander, some other race, unknown race, or declined to answer); ethnicity included Hispanic

sections.title: Key Points
sections.text:
Question Can bulk ordering and text messaging with behavioral insights boost the effectiveness of lipid screening outreach? Findings In this randomized clinical trial with 1000 participants, patient outreach with bulk ordering resulted in higher lipid screening uptake than usual care. Adding behaviorally informed text messaging did not significantly increase uptake.

Meaning Bulk orders are a low-cost intervention that may both reduce effort for patients and clinicians and increase uptake of lipid screening; text messaging does not provide significant additional benefit. and non-Hispanic. Household income was estimated using the 2018-2022 American Community Survey 5-year estimate data for median income by zip code of residence.

sections.title: Interventions
sections.text:
Eligible patients were randomized with a factor of 2-fold more participants in each of the intervention groups (1:2:2 ratio), stratified by practice and age cohort (20-39 years and 40-75 years). Randomization and text messaging were conducted using the Way to Health (W2H) software platform (Penn Medicine).

Patients in group 1 received usual care with no additional intervention from this study. Patients in group 2 received an outreach letter mailed to their physical address with a physical bulk-ordered laboratory slip signed by the regional medical director and the patient's PCP as the clinician who would receive the results. The outreach letter was sent by the health system and endorsed by the patient's named PCP. It described the importance of cholesterol screening, informed the patient that they were overdue, and invited the patient to use their laboratory slip within 6 weeks at any laboratory of their choice. The letter contained information about how to schedule an appointment through the electronic patient portal or by telephone. It provided specific information about 3 laboratories closest to the patient's primary care practice and walk-in hours, although patients could go to any laboratory.

Patients in group 3 received the same outreach letter and laboratory slip as those in group 2, with additional text messaging. A first text message was sent on day 0 to introduce the outreach and inform the patient that they would receive a laboratory order. Patients could opt out from receiving messages by texting "STOP." A second text message was sent on day 14 to patients who had not yet completed their testing. This text message invited patients with an electronic patient portal account to schedule through their account, and patients without the portal received a link with contact information to the closest laboratories. Patients could start a conversation if they had questions. A third reminder message was sent on day 28 to those who had not yet completed their testing, highlighting the walk-in options available, with the times at the closest laboratories. Patients with questions were informed that their inquiries would be answered within 1 to 3 business days. Automated answers were prepared to answer the most common questions that had been identified in a preliminary study. Other questions were answered by the study team through the backend W2H system.

We did not monitor for adverse events because the intervention was considered low risk and part of routine clinical practice.

sections.title: Study Outcomes
sections.text: The primary outcome was the percentage of patients who completed the lipid panel within 3 months. The secondary outcome was the percentage of patients who completed the lipid panel within 6 months. Additional outcomes included the proportion of patients with an elevated ASCVD risk score among participants who completed the lipid panel, and the pro-portion of patients who initiated a statin prescription or had a dosage escalation among all participants. Lipid completion data were obtained from the EHR through automated data extraction. For patients who had self-reported having completed a lipid panel (by replying "DONE" to the text messages) but for whom no corresponding screening was found in the EHR, a medical record review was also conducted to find evidence of a screening.

sections.title: Statistical Analysis
sections.text:
For a 1:2:2 ratio of randomization, we included 1000 eligible patients (200 in group 1, 400 in group 2, and 400 in group 3). We estimated a 3% response rate to usual care (group 1) based on prior outreach trials at this health system. We considered a meaningful increase in response rate to be 8 percentage points for group 2 compared with group 1 and for group 3 compared with group 2. These increases would justify investment by the health system in the additional resources required for outreach, bulk ordering, and additional text messaging outreach. Using a χ 2 test, the sample size yielded 91% power to detect an 8-percentage point increase in completion for group 2 compared with group 1 and 82% power to detect an 8-percentage point increase in group 3 completion compared with group 2. The familywise 2-sided type I error rate was .05, and the power calculation included a Bonferroni adjustment for the 2 planned comparisons (group 2 vs group 1 and group 3 vs group 2).

The primary intention-to-treat analysis was a comparison of the proportion of patients across groups who had a lipid panel completion within 3 and 6 months after the intervention start. We used χ 2 tests to evaluate the overall differences in response rate between the 3 groups (group 2 vs group 1 and group 3 vs group 2).

sections.title: Participants
sections.text: Figure  1  shows that 202 patients were randomized to group 1, 394 to group 2, and 404 to group 3; all 1000 patients were included in the final intention-to-treat analysis. Among these, 2 participants in group 2 did not receive a bulk order due to an order failure, 5 participants in group 3 did not receive text messages due to an incorrect cellular phone number, and 45 participants in group 3 asked to opt out from receiving messages. The median (IQR) age was 38 (28-55) years; 470 (47.0%) were women. Among the participants, 849 (84.9%) had commercial insurance, 107 (10.7%) were insured by Medi-care, and 44 (4.4%) were insured by Medicaid. A total of 22 (2.3%) were Asian, 38 (3.9%) were Black, 32 (3.2%) were Hispanic or Latino, and 862 (88.6%) were White. The mean (SD) of the median income was $114 320 ($26 172) (Table  1 ). The intervention was conducted from June 7, 2023 (first text message and outreach letter), through July 19, 2023 (end of text messaging and due date for lipid screening at 6 weeks); the 6-month follow-up period was completed on December 7, 2023.

sections.title: Lipid Screening Completion
sections.text: At 3 months, 147 of 1000 participants (14.7%) had completed a lipid screening, including 12 of 202 patients (5.9%; 95% CI, 3.4% to 10.1%) in group 1 (usual care) vs 62 of 394 patients (15.7%; 95% CI, 12.5% to 19.7%) in group 2 (bulk order and outreach) and 73 of 404 (18.1%; 95% CI, 14.6% to 22.1%) in group 3 (bulk order and outreach plus text messaging). Bulk order and outreach (group 2) significantly improved uptake by 9.8 percentage points (95% CI, 4.6 to 15.0; P = .001) compared with usual care (group 1) (Table  2 ). The addition of text messaging to bulk order and outreach (group 3) did not significantly alter uptake compared with bulk order and outreach (group 2) (mean improvement of 2.4 percentage points; 95% CI, -3.1 to 7.8; P = .43). These results include 22 participants (2.2% of the sample) who were later found to have completed lipid screening after randomization and prior to the intervention; these patients were included in the intention-to-treat analysis as completers of lipid screening and were evenly distributed across study groups. 2 ). At 6 months, ASCVD risk could be calculated for 98 (74.8%) of 131 patients aged 40 to 75 years who had completed a lipid screening during the intervention period. Among them, 11 of 86 patients (12.7%) with ASCVD risk score calculated in groups 2 and 3 were found to have a high risk score (eTable 1 in Supplement 2). Medication changes in the intervention period were evenly distributed across study groups (eTable 2 in Supplement 2). Follow-up visits after lipid panel completion were not reduced by the intervention (eTable 3 in Supplement 2).

sections.title: Subgroup Analyses
sections.text: Figure  3 , which shows the estimated odds ratio and 95% CI of the overall treatment effect and in each subgroup, suggests little evidence of treatment effect heterogeneity across subgroups. A test of an interaction between each subgroup and treatment arm yielded P < .05 in 0 cases; by chance, we conservatively expected approximately 1 test to yield P < .05.

sections.title: Text Message Results
sections.text: A total of 404 patients were sent any text message outreach. Of those, 45 (11.1%) indicated they did not want to receive further messages, 7 indicated they had completed screening (having replied "DONE") after the first reminder, 6 did so after the second reminder, and 8 patients replied with questions.

sections.title: Discussion
sections.text:
In this clinical trial, text bulk ordering and mailed outreach resulted in a statistically significant 9.8-percentage point increase in lipid screening uptake compared with usual care at 3 months, with lipid screening completion rates of 15.7% in the bulk ordering group and 5.9% in the usual care group. Rates of lipid screening at 3 months in usual care were higher than anticipated before the study launch. Adding text messaging to mailed outreach yielded a small and nonsignificant 2.4percentage point improvement in uptake. However, at 6 months, there was no significant difference between bulk ordering and usual care. At 6 months, completed lipid panels enabled the calculation of an ASCVD risk score among older patients, identifying 11 new patients (12.7%) at high risk. Lipid testing was not associated with an increase in prescription of statin medications at 3 or 6 months.

There are a few reasons that might explain these findings. Lipid screening is a preventive routine check that might not be proposed to patients who otherwise do not show cardiovascular risk factors and who consult their PCP for different and more urgent needs. Bulk ordering for lipid screening facilitates this screening for both the PCP and the patient: it acts as a default on both sides and makes the process of screening by removing the need for a clinic visit. In addition, this trial was informed by prior outreach studies  7  and a smaller pilot study of 100 patients with qualitative feedback that the outreach should include PCP endorsement, a time-limited call to action, a physically mailed laboratory order, and scheduling assistance. Indeed, reaching out to patients via the electronic patient portal may not be as effective as through mailed letters, because even among electronic portal users, some patients are more likely to overlook this information than an official mailed letter or possibly not know how to use an electronic laboratory order. From an equity perspective, mailed letters are the only cost-effective option for patients with limited internet use. However, a notable finding is that the magnitude of the effect from bulk ordering and outreach was lower than in other studies, which found that hepatitis C screening went from 19% for direct outreach alone to 42% with bulk ordering with a similar laboratory slip  8  and that opt-out mailed colorectal cancer screening tripled participation.  7 In this case, even with bulk ordering, more than 80% of patients did not undergo lipid testing after 3 months. This behavioral intervention was intended to facilitate intention and memory and can serve as a low-cost complement to increase lipid screening. However, more work is needed to boost uptake by addressing other barriers for preventive screening. Convincing patients of the importance of screening may require more interaction with a health professional. Practical barriers may also need to be addressed for certain patients, for example, by home testing. Another notable conclusion is that we did not find an effect from bulk ordering and outreach at 6 months. The fact that the intervention was only effective in the short term may suggest that there was some spillover in prescribing of lipid panels by the clinicians or that engageable patients in all 3 groups were reached either by the intervention in the first 3 months or through regular clinical care in months 4 through 6.

Although the differences between the outreach, bulk order, and text messaging group and the outreach and bulk order intervention alone were not significant, the text messaging group produced marginally higher lipid panel completion. sections.title: Strengths and Limitations
sections.text:
The notable advantages of this study include its prospective design with patient-level randomization. This trial was seamlessly integrated into a real-world clinical environment, spanning many PCPs, and had very few patient exclusions.

This study also has limitations. It was conducted at an academic health system with existing primary care patients. Although the look-back interval was expansive at 3 years, most of these patients were seen by their PCP in the last year and had received lipid screenings in the past, so they were generally well engaged in health care. While we were able to use registry data to track lipid screenings outside our health system, we likely missed some lipid outcomes outside this network. The intervention pursued a paper-based letter and laboratory order strategy, but there may be value in a more tailored outreach strategy based on individual patient communication preferences, for example, using patients' use of their elec-tronic health portal. Also, the study group was insured, predominantly White, and relatively affluent, reflecting the characteristics of the region where the study was conducted. Further research and replication in multicenter studies or community health centers would be necessary to inform the effectiveness of this intervention in population groups who have more limited access to health care.

sections.title: Conclusions
sections.text: In this clinical trial, text bulk ordering and mailed outreach resulted in a significant increase in lipid screening compared with usual care at 3 months. Bulk ordering associated with mailed outreach is a feasible, low-cost modality that can improve uptake of lipid screening. However, we did not find significant further increases in lipid screening by adding complementary text message reminders and scheduling assistance. With these interventions, up to one-fifth of patients who are overdue can be encouraged to have their lipids screened and to be assessed for cardiovascular risk. However, bulk ordering did not significantly increase uptake of lipid screening compared with usual care at 6 months, and more than 80% of patients did not follow through with lipid testing within 3 months despite the intervention. To further narrow the gap and achieve guideline adherence, future efforts should focus on more intensive or tailored outreach and reducing barriers to screening through engagement in primary care practices and for patients who have limited engagement with health care.
